title: How to Unjam a Staple Gun

steps.headline: Slide out the pusher rod.
steps.description: This rod runs the length of the magazine, pushing staples up and feeding them into the gun’s chamber. You’ll usually find a knob or tab at the bottom of the staple gun which is connected to this rod. Simply grab it and it pull. You may have to push in to clear the latching spot.

steps.headline: Remove the screw at the bottom of the magazine.
steps.description: This screw prevents the magazine from falling out or being removed. Use a screwdriver to remove the screw and set it aside. Some staple guns have locking screws at the bottom; they have a nut on one side which must be held in place before you can remove the screw. Hold the nut with a pair of pliers while you unscrew the rest.

steps.headline: Take out the magazine.
steps.description: After removing the screw, you should be able to reach in and remove the staple gun’s magazine easily. It’ll come out the bottom of the staple gun.

steps.headline: Use needle-nose pliers to clear the jam.
steps.description: With this kind of stapler, the jam will happen at the very top, where the staples are discharged. You should be able to see the staple stuck there. Use the pliers to pinch the staple and pull towards you, pulling the staple out of the stapler’s nose.

steps.headline: Reassemble the stapler.
steps.description: Start by inserting the magazine into the staple gun. Then, add in the retaining screw, followed by the pusher rod. You’ll essentially be following the same process as you did during the disassembly, only reversed.

methods.name: Unjamming Electric or Pneumatic Staple Guns

steps.headline: Release the trigger and unplug the staple gun.
steps.description: If you feel like a staple is jammed, don’t try to dislodge it by pulling the trigger again. In some models, internal safeties will prevent a jammed gun from firing. After releasing the trigger, unplug corded staple guns. If the gun has a switch, turn it off. If it’s battery powered, remove the battery pack. If the gun is pneumatic, release it from the air hose.

steps.headline: Remove the staple clip.
steps.description: You’ll usually find a small lever at the bottom of the magazine. This is the release lever. Pull on the lever, and the magazine should unclip. You’ll then be able to pull on the magazine until it’s clear of the staple gun.

steps.headline: Remove staples at the front of the magazine with needle-nose pliers.
steps.description: Some jams are caused by staples failing to properly leave the magazine. They might be partially crushed by the other staples in the clip. Other times, the staple will have partially left the magazine and will be stuck in the opening. Use needle-nose pliers to remove the staple from the magazine, gently pulling it out. Be gentle when trying to remove staples from the magazine or you’ll risk causing damage to it.

steps.headline: Use needle-nose pliers to remove staples in the discharge area.
steps.description: You might find a jam here if a staple leaves the magazine but stays stuck before leaving the nose. Use a pair of needle-nose pliers to reach the jam and pinch the staple to remove it. Be careful not to damage the staple gun as you do this. In many models you’ll be able to reach this kind of jam simply by removing the magazine. In others, you may need to disassemble part of the gun. Check the owner’s manual to determine if that’s the case. Sometimes a tap on the base of the gun can help clear a jammed staple.

steps.headline: Some Swingline staple guns don't have a screw to open the staple gun - check if this is the case.
Look at the front of the staple gun - it should say "OPEN" and an arrow pointing downward.
Hammer the front section of the staple gun downward until it comes off.
Press down the lever to shoot out the jammed staple - be careful not to aim it at yourself.
Put the front panel back and hammer it back in place.

text: Fixing Manual Staple Guns Slide out the pusher rod. This rod runs the length of the magazine, pushing staples up and feeding them into the gun’s chamber. You’ll usually find a knob or tab at the bottom of the staple gun which is connected to this rod. Simply grab it and it pull. You may have to push in to clear the latching spot. Remove the screw at the bottom of the magazine. This screw prevents the magazine from falling out or being removed. Use a screwdriver to remove the screw and set it aside. Some staple guns have locking screws at the bottom; they have a nut on one side which must be held in place before you can remove the screw. Hold the nut with a pair of pliers while you unscrew the rest. Take out the magazine. After removing the screw, you should be able to reach in and remove the staple gun’s magazine easily. It’ll come out the bottom of the staple gun. Use needle-nose pliers to clear the jam. With this kind of stapler, the jam will happen at the very top, where the staples are discharged. You should be able to see the staple stuck there. Use the pliers to pinch the staple and pull towards you, pulling the staple out of the stapler’s nose. Reassemble the stapler. Start by inserting the magazine into the staple gun. Then, add in the retaining screw, followed by the pusher rod. You’ll essentially be following the same process as you did during the disassembly, only reversed. Unjamming Electric or Pneumatic Staple Guns Release the trigger and unplug the staple gun. If you feel like a staple is jammed, don’t try to dislodge it by pulling the trigger again. In some models, internal safeties will prevent a jammed gun from firing. After releasing the trigger, unplug corded staple guns. If the gun has a switch, turn it off. If it’s battery powered, remove the battery pack. If the gun is pneumatic, release it from the air hose. Remove the staple clip. You’ll usually find a small lever at the bottom of the magazine. This is the release lever. Pull on the lever, and the magazine should unclip. You’ll then be able to pull on the magazine until it’s clear of the staple gun. Remove staples at the front of the magazine with needle-nose pliers. Some jams are caused by staples failing to properly leave the magazine. They might be partially crushed by the other staples in the clip. Other times, the staple will have partially left the magazine and will be stuck in the opening. Use needle-nose pliers to remove the staple from the magazine, gently pulling it out. Be gentle when trying to remove staples from the magazine or you’ll risk causing damage to it. Use needle-nose pliers to remove staples in the discharge area. You might find a jam here if a staple leaves the magazine but stays stuck before leaving the nose. Use a pair of needle-nose pliers to reach the jam and pinch the staple to remove it. Be careful not to damage the staple gun as you do this. In many models you’ll be able to reach this kind of jam simply by removing the magazine. In others, you may need to disassemble part of the gun. Check the owner’s manual to determine if that’s the case. Sometimes a tap on the base of the gun can help clear a jammed staple. Fixing Staple Gun Without Screw Some Swingline staple guns don't have a screw to open the staple gun - check if this is the case.  Look at the front of the staple gun - it should say "OPEN" and an arrow pointing downward.  Hammer the front section of the staple gun downward until it comes off.  Press down the lever to shoot out the jammed staple - be careful not to aim it at yourself.  Put the front panel back and hammer it back in place.
